objtitle.title: Countess Aveline, Detail from Her Tomb

objdescid.origination: anonymous delineator. The gold coloring may have been added by someone other than Blake. The inscriptions are not by Blake; see the Textual Transcription.
objdescid.compdate: c. 1775This monument was uncovered in the presbytery of Westminster Abbey in the summer of 1775 and was covered again by 1778. Blake probably drew this design shortly after the monument was revealed.

objinfo.medium: pen and ink with shell goldThe gold tinting may have been added by someone other than Blake. The inscription upper left is in pencil. The collection mark of the Society of Antiquaries, stamped in black ink, appears along the lower left side of the triangular design.

provenance.name: Society of Antiquaries, London
provenance.note: The Society of Antiquaries commissioned Blake's engraving master, James Basire, to execute this drawing. Basire assigned Blake to this task. The drawing was presumably delivered to the Society shortly after its engraving for Joseph Ayloffe, *An Account of Some Ancient Monuments in Westminster Abbey*, first published by the Society of Antiquaries in 1780.

Countess Aveline, Detail from Her Tomb,
object 1 (Butlin 6)

illustration.illusobjdesc: This drawing shows the ornament on the spandrels in the pediment of the canopy over the tomb of Countess Aveline in Westminster Abbey. Swirling vegetative forms appear within an inverse triangular form with a concave upper boundary. These forms, which appear to constitute a single branch or vine, originate in the upper left corner of the triangle. The branch extends rightward before curving down in a serpentine shape, where it divides into two branches in the middle of the triangle, with the leftmost branch curving to the left and up while the rightmost side extends further down before curving up and to the right. Nine five-pointed leaves and fifteen bunches of berries extend from the main branch or vine. An engraving that included this design, signed by Blake's engraving master James Basire, was published in Joseph Ayloffe, An Account of Some Ancient Monuments in Westminster Abbey, 1780, also published (or republished) as plate 31 in volume 2 of Vetusta Monumenta, published by the Society of Antiquaries c. 1789.
